qas.question: From what did Chinese characters derive?
What is another name for the Yue language?
Hakka is a language from what geographic part of China?
From the time of the Ming dynasty, what city was the capital of China?
At its founding. what was the official language of the Republic of China?
What do Chinese characters use to give hints to pronunciation?
What is another name for the Xiang language?
Where is Macau the most commonly used language?
Which language is the most commonly used in Cantonese?
What do most languages use to indicate varieties?

context: Unlike most languages that use <b9_0>alphabets<b9_0/> to indicate the pronunciation, Chinese characters have developed from <a0_0><b5_0>logograms<b5_0/><a0_0/> that do not always give hints to its pronunciation. Although the written characters remained relatively consistent for the last two thousand years, the pronunciation and grammar in different regions has developed to an extent that the varieties of the spoken language are often mutually unintelligible. As a series of migration to <a2_0>the south<a2_0/> throughout the history, the regional languages of the south, including Xiang, Wu, Gan, Min, Yue (<a1_0><b6_0>Cantonese<b6_0/><a1_0/>), and Hakka often show traces of Old Chinese or Middle Chinese. From the Ming dynasty onward, <a3_0>Beijing<a3_0/> has been the capital of China and the dialect spoken in Beijing has had the most prestige among other varieties. With the founding of the Republic of China, <a4_0>Standard Mandarin<a4_0/> was designated as the official language, based on the spoken language of Beijing. Since then, other spoken varieties are regarded as fangyan (dialects). Cantonese is still the most commonly used language in <b7_0><b8_0>Hong Kong<b8_0/><b7_0/>, Macau and among some overseas Chinese communities, whereas Southern Min has been accepted in Taiwan as an important local language along with Mandarin.
